text: Art that endures is sincere.
author: Albert Sterner
citation: Albert Sterner, "Sincerity" in Pictorial Photography in America, 1922 (1922), Project Gutenberg ebook #28024.

text: If over and above his technical skill the photographer starts with a 'vital idea,' he may like the painter convey with his photograph 'the moving thrill' which is the final test of any work of art.
author: Albert Sterner
citation: Albert Sterner, "Sincerity" in Pictorial Photography in America, 1922 (1922), Project Gutenberg ebook #28024.

text: To many people photography is merely a mechanical process. To an increasing number, however, photography is being seen as an art, by which personal impressions of nature or human life may be expressed as truly as by the brush.
author: Clarence H. White
citation: Clarence H. White, Foreword in Pictorial Photography in America, 1920 (1920), Project Gutenberg ebook #28015.

text: Imagination is nothing more than the power to see and realize what others fail to see and realize.
author: Arthur Brisbane
work: Quoted in "On Ideas" (Pictorial Photography in America, 1922)
citation: Arthur Brisbane (quoted in Heyworth Campbell, "On Ideas" in Pictorial Photography in America, 1922), Project Gutenberg ebook #28024.

text: Ideas, to be sure, you must seek. But orderly thought, patience and fine craftsmanship in carrying out your idea frequently count for more than the originality or brilliance of the idea itself.
author: Heyworth Campbell
work: On Ideas (in Pictorial Photography in America, 1922)
citation: Heyworth Campbell, "On Ideas" in Pictorial Photography in America, 1922 (1922), Project Gutenberg ebook #28024.

text: From fairest creatures we desire increase,

text: Full of sweet dreams, and health, and quiet breathing.
author: John Keats
citation: John Keats, Endymion: A Poetic Romance (1818), Project Gutenberg ebook #24280.

text: From our dark spirits. Such the sun, the moon,
author: John Keats
citation: John Keats, Endymion: A Poetic Romance (1818), Project Gutenberg ebook #24280.

text: Rich with a sprinkling of fair musk-rose blooms:
author: John Keats

text: Dear as the temple's self, so does the moon,

text: With April's tender younglings: next, well trimm'd,

text: Than Leda's love, and cresses from the rill.
